## ğŸ“ 8th Grade Physics Revision Sheet

---

### **Chapter-by-Chapter Bullets**

#### **Force and Pressure**
* Force: A push or a pull. Can change the state of motion or shape of an object.
* Contact Forces: Muscular, Frictional.
* Non-Contact Forces: Magnetic, Electrostatic, Gravitational.
* Pressure: Force per unit area.
* Atmospheric Pressure: Pressure exerted by the air column on Earth.

#### **Friction**
* Opposes motion between surfaces.
* Types: Static, Sliding, Rolling.
* Rolling friction < Sliding friction.
* Friction is useful (walking) but also causes wear.
* Methods to reduce friction: Lubrication, ball bearings, streamlining.

#### **Sound**
* Produced by vibrating bodies.
* Requires a medium to travel (cannot travel in vacuum).
* Characteristics: Amplitude (loudness), Frequency (pitch), Time period.
* Audible range: 20 Hzâ€“20,000 Hz.
* Noise pollution caused by unwanted sound.

#### **Chemical Effects of Electric Current**
* Some liquids conduct electricity (electrolytes).
* Electrolysis causes chemical reactions.
* Electroplating coats one metal on another.

#### **Light**
* Reflection: Bouncing of light.
* Laws: âˆ i = âˆ r, rays and normal in same plane.
* Image in plane mirror: Virtual, erect, same size, laterally inverted.
* Dispersion: Splitting of white light into colours.
* Human Eye: Cornea, Iris, Pupil, Lens, Retina.

#### **Some Natural Phenomena**
* Electric Charge: Produced by rubbing.
* Lightning: Caused by discharge of charges.
* Earthquake: Tremor due to tectonic movement.
* Safety: Lightning conductor, Drop-Cover-Hold during quakes.

---

### **Definitions/Formulas**
| Concept | Formula | Unit |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Force | F = ma | Newton (N) |
| Pressure | P = F/A | Pascal (Pa) |
| Frequency | f = 1/T | Hertz (Hz) |
| Speed | v = s/t | m/s |
| Voltage | V = IR | Volt (V) |

---

### **Diagrams to Remember**
* Contact & Non-contact forces
* Friction on slope
* Human Ear
* Electrolysis setup
* Laws of Reflection
* Solar System

---

### **Exam Tips**
* Always write SI units.
* Label diagrams neatly.
* Practice numerical problems.
* Learn real-life examples.
* Revise differences (contact/non-contact, static/sliding friction, noise/music).
